Award.AwardTitle: Marine Advanced Technology Education Center Resource Center 2011

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center is a national partnership of community colleges, high schools, universities, informal educational organizations, research institutions, marine industries, professional societies, and working professionals. MATE's mission is to improve marine technical education and increase the number of highly-skilled technical professionals who enter ocean-related occupations. The Center characterizes and researches trends in the ocean workforce, identifies the knowledge and skills this workforce needs, places this information in the hands of educational institutions at all levels, and works to ensure that curricula and programs are appropriately preparing students to meet workforce needs. MATE's programs represent unique approaches to engaging students in STEM learning experiences and developing the capacity for increasing the nation's technological workforce. The geographic distribution of MATE partners makes products of this Center available to a broad audience; the strategies developed as a result of MATE's research into barriers of participation help to engage and involve traditionally underrepresented groups. These efforts prepare a diverse workforce that ensures U.S. competitiveness in a global economy that is currently, and increasingly, dependent on ocean activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center was established as an ATE Center of Excellence in 1997 with funding from the National Science Foundation.  Headquartered at Monterey Peninsula College (MPC) in Monterey, California, the Center is a national partnership of community colleges, secondary schools, universities, informal educational organizations, research institutions, marine industries, professional societies, and working professionals.  MATE’s mission is to improve science and technology education and to provide the marine workforce with well-educated technical professionals. A hallmark of all MATE’s programs, products and services is that they are aligned with ocean workforce research and trends.  Over the past five years the MATE has:

  • Maintained relationships with more than 800 academic institutions at all levels. Since MATE’s inception approximately 9,000 students have enrolled in marine technology-related programs at its community college partners; 4,000 of these students have earned marine technology-related certificates or degrees.  According to MATE partner community colleges, 14,500 students have benefited from the infusion of MATE curriculum modules into their college curriculum.
  • Received more than $1,300,000 in funds from over 100 industry partners and over $6,600,000 in in-kind contributions (equipment, facilities, time) from many more. Our industry partners have hired MATE students and, specifically, used the ROV competition and the internship program to recruit new hires.
  • Held one international and 23 regional competitions underwater robotics (ROV) competitions annually over the past five years. To date, the competitions have impacted more than 25,000 students and 2,000 teachers at more than 1000 formal and informal educational institutions (middle schools, high schools, home schools, community colleges, universities, 4-H clubs, and public aquaria). Visit www.marinetech.org/videos to view MATE competition videos.
  • The MATE Underwater Robotics competition was the focus of two films (a documentary, Underwater Dreams, and a major motion picture, Spare Parts) and a book (also called Spare Parts).
  • In 2012 the MATE Center created SeaMATE.  SeaMATE is a social enterprise that provides community college students with income and work experience while generating products that support marine technical education.  Students participating in SeaMATE create ROV kits and other merchandise that are then sold in MATE’s on-line store (see www.marinetech.org/store/).  These products were originally created to support teams participating in MATE’s ROV competitions and now are used in science projects, summer camps, and aquariums.  In 2015, SeaMATE sold 543 ROV kits (ranging in price from $185 to $635) and took in $297,405 in sales.  
  • By December 31, 2015, more than 2,300 copies of MATE’s textbook, Underwater Robotics:  Science, Design & Fabrication, had been sold ($115.00 retail price). Excerpts of the book can be viewed here www.marinetech.org/underwater_robotics/. 
  • More than 100 detailed educational modules and videos have been developed by MATE staff and education partners to accompany the topics in this textbook (see http://www.marinetech.org/curriculum/).  In June 2013 MATE created a password protection site for our curriculum products.   In 2015, 29,857 different users logged in to view these resources. 
  • MATE has developed detailed occupational guidelines for seven marine occupations that can be viewed herehttp://www.marinetech.org/workforce/.  The integration of these guidelines with more than 50 other marine careers can be found at www.oceancareers.com, a MATE product produced with NSF funding from a COSEE grant.  In addition, the Center disseminates workforce information through the website and in/at webinars, conferences, and faculty workshops. 
  • Since its inception in 1999, MATE’s technical internship program has placed 315 students in at-sea and shore-based internship positions. MATE interns work with marine technicians and scientists aboard research vessels. These experiences provide them with the opportunity to develop their technical, scientific, seamanship, and interpersonal skills. The MATE Center has longitudinal data for 75% of these interns. From a 2014 survey, 26% of past interns are continuing their education in a STEM field; 40% are working in marine science and technology positions; 17% are working in a STEM field other than marine science and technology; and 7% are educators in a STEM subject. 
  • Beginning in the summer of 1999, MATE began providing two week-long summer professional development Institutes for secondary school and college faculty focused on marine technology, ROVs, and Ocean Observing Systems and GIS topics. The Institutes provide participants with hands-on time with technology, curriculum materials, lectures, videos, demonstrations, and field trips.  More than 800 faculty have participated in these workshops. For example, in 2015 the 40 teacher participants went on to build 500+ underwater robots with more than 2000 students.
  • MATE partners have used and adapted MATE materials to conduct outreach in their communities. Over the past 5 year MATE partners have run 124 workshops and participated in engineering fairs and other outreach events that have impact more than 20,000 students and teachers.
  • Maintains two web sites, www.marinetech.org and www.OceanCareers.com, which hundreds of thousands people visit each year.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2016
Modified by: Deidre Sullivan

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center was established as an ATE Center of Excellence in 1997 with funding from the National Science Foundation. Headquartered at Monterey Peninsula College (MPC) in Monterey, California, the Center is a national partnership of community colleges, secondary schools, universities, informal educational organizations, research institutions, marine industries, professional societies, and working professionals. MATE?s mission is to improve science and technology education and to provide the marine workforce with well-educated technical professionals. A hallmark of all MATE?s programs, products and services is that they are aligned with ocean workforce research and trends. Over the past five years the MATE has: Maintained relationships with more than 800 academic institutions at all levels. Since MATE?s inception approximately 9,000 students have enrolled in marine technology-related programs at its community college partners; 4,000 of these students have earned marine technology-related certificates or degrees. According to MATE partner community colleges, 14,500 students have benefited from the infusion of MATE curriculum modules into their college curriculum. Received more than $1,300,000 in funds from over 100 industry partners and over $6,600,000 in in-kind contributions (equipment, facilities, time) from many more. Our industry partners have hired MATE students and, specifically, used the ROV competition and the internship program to recruit new hires. Held one international and 23 regional competitions underwater robotics (ROV) competitions annually over the past five years. To date, the competitions have impacted more than 25,000 students and 2,000 teachers at more than 1000 formal and informal educational institutions (middle schools, high schools, home schools, community colleges, universities, 4-H clubs, and public aquaria). Visit www.marinetech.org/videos to view MATE competition videos. The MATE Underwater Robotics competition was the focus of two films (a documentary, Underwater Dreams, and a major motion picture, Spare Parts) and a book (also called Spare Parts). In 2012 the MATE Center created SeaMATE. SeaMATE is a social enterprise that provides community college students with income and work experience while generating products that support marine technical education. Students participating in SeaMATE create ROV kits and other merchandise that are then sold in MATE?s on-line store (see www.marinetech.org/store/). These products were originally created to support teams participating in MATE?s ROV competitions and now are used in science projects, summer camps, and aquariums. In 2015, SeaMATE sold 543 ROV kits (ranging in price from $185 to $635) and took in $297,405 in sales. By December 31, 2015, more than 2,300 copies of MATE?s textbook, Underwater Robotics: Science, Design & Fabrication, had been sold ($115.00 retail price). Excerpts of the book can be viewed here www.marinetech.org/underwater_robotics/. More than 100 detailed educational modules and videos have been developed by MATE staff and education partners to accompany the topics in this textbook (see http://www.marinetech.org/curriculum/). In June 2013 MATE created a password protection site for our curriculum products. In 2015, 29,857 different users logged in to view these resources. MATE has developed detailed occupational guidelines for seven marine occupations that can be viewed herehttp://www.marinetech.org/workforce/. The integration of these guidelines with more than 50 other marine careers can be found at www.oceancareers.com, a MATE product produced with NSF funding from a COSEE grant. In addition, the Center disseminates workforce information through the website and in/at webinars, conferences, and faculty workshops. Since its inception in 1999, MATE?s technical internship program has placed 315 students in at-sea and shore-based internship positions. MATE interns work with marine technicians and scientists aboard research vessels. These experiences provide them with the opportunity to develop their technical, scientific, seamanship, and interpersonal skills. The MATE Center has longitudinal data for 75% of these interns. From a 2014 survey, 26% of past interns are continuing their education in a STEM field; 40% are working in marine science and technology positions; 17% are working in a STEM field other than marine science and technology; and 7% are educators in a STEM subject. Beginning in the summer of 1999, MATE began providing two week-long summer professional development Institutes for secondary school and college faculty focused on marine technology, ROVs, and Ocean Observing Systems and GIS topics. The Institutes provide participants with hands-on time with technology, curriculum materials, lectures, videos, demonstrations, and field trips. More than 800 faculty have participated in these workshops. For example, in 2015 the 40 teacher participants went on to build 500+ underwater robots with more than 2000 students. MATE partners have used and adapted MATE materials to conduct outreach in their communities. Over the past 5 year MATE partners have run 124 workshops and participated in engineering fairs and other outreach events that have impact more than 20,000 students and teachers. Maintains two web sites, www.marinetech.org and www.OceanCareers.com, which hundreds of thousands people visit each year. Last Modified: 10/25/2016 Submitted by: Deidre Sullivan
